summary: This is a transcript of a civil conference before Magistrate Judge Debra C. Freeman regarding multiple lawsuits filed by victims (Jane Does) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein. The conference addresses case management, coordination among numerous plaintiffs' attorneys, the estate's proposed victim compensation fund administered by Kenneth Feinberg and Jordana Feldman, and initial discovery and settlement discussions.

persons.name: Debra C. Freeman
persons.context: Presiding over the conference, explaining her role in case management and urging cooperation on settlement and discovery.

persons.name: Bennet Moskowitz
persons.role: Attorney for co-executors of Epstein Estate
persons.context: Represents the Epstein estate defendants; explains the proposed victim compensation fund and argues for staying litigation in favor of the fund process.

persons.name: Roberta Kaplan
persons.context: Counsel for a pseudonymous plaintiff; criticizes the estate for unilaterally creating a settlement fund without plaintiff input and raises concerns about estate assets and victim agency.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Represents multiple plaintiffs including VE; argues against delaying litigation for a vague settlement process and suggests cases could go to trial quickly.

persons.name: Arick W. Fudali
persons.context: Attorney for Jane Doe 1; expresses plaintiffs are 'in the dark' about settlement details and anticipates filing more lawsuits.

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.context: Represents five victims; echoes concerns about the unilateral selection of claims administrators and is open to settlement discussions.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Represents victims; suggests setting a court conference date to spur progress on settlement discussions.

persons.name: Kenneth Feinberg
persons.context: Selected by the estate as a leading claims administration expert to help design the victim compensation program.

persons.name: Jordana Feldman
persons.context: Selected to administer the victim compensation program; described as having deep empathy for victims from her work on the 9/11 fund.

persons.name: Camille Viras
persons.context: Selected as a claims administration expert to work with Feinberg on designing the program.

persons.name: Brittany Henderson
persons.context: Plaintiffs' attorney present at the conference.

persons.name: Kate Donneger
persons.context: Plaintiffs' attorney present at the conference.

persons.name: David Brody
persons.context: Plaintiffs' attorney present at the conference.

persons.name: Laura Star
persons.context: Plaintiffs' attorney present at the conference.

persons.name: Alan Goldfarb
persons.context: Represents Jane Doe 17; suggests hearing directly from claims administrators in court and proposes an earlier status conference.

persons.name: Andrew Posen
persons.context: Plaintiffs' attorney present at the conference.

persons.name: Josh Schiller
persons.context: Plaintiffs' attorney present at the conference.

persons.name: Marion Wang
persons.context: Announces filing of a new case, bringing her firm's total to three.

persons.name: Charles Glover
persons.context: Colleague of Bennet Moskowitz representing the estate.

persons.name: Hannah Martin
persons.context: Law clerk to Judge Freeman, identified as a contact for chambers.

persons.name: Mary Greco
persons.context: Certified the transcript from the electronic recording.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The accused perpetrator whose estate is the defendant in the civil lawsuits.

connections.description: Moskowitz, representing the estate, states the co-executors selected Feinberg as an independent claims administrator for the victim compensation program.
Moskowitz states the estate selected Feldman to administer the victim compensation program.
Kaplan criticizes Moskowitz and the estate for creating a settlement process unilaterally without plaintiff input, creating tension.
Edwards disagrees with Moskowitz on litigation timing and the settlement process, but they have been conferring on issues like pseudonymity.
Both were selected as part of the team to design and administer the Epstein victim compensation program.
Both are attorneys representing five of the victim plaintiffs in the coordinated cases.

events.title: Civil Case Management Conference
events.description: Magistrate Judge Debra Freeman holds a conference with attorneys from multiple civil cases against the Epstein estate to discuss coordination, settlement via a proposed victim fund, and preliminary discovery issues.

events.title: Rule 26 Conference in VE case
events.description: Attorneys Brad Edwards and Bennet Moskowitz held a Rule 26 conference for the case VE v. Nine East 71st Street, et al.

events.title: Scheduled Initial Pretrial Conference
events.description: An initial pretrial conference is scheduled before Judge Alison Nathan in the VE case.

events.title: Filing for Claims Administration Process
events.description: The co-executors of the Epstein estate filed an application in the US Virgin Islands probate court for expedited approval of a victim claims administration process.

events.title: Court-Ordered Status Report Deadline
events.description: Judge Freeman orders all parties to file status reports by January 10, 2020, on the progress of settlement talks and plans for moving the cases forward.

locations: United States District Court, Southern District of New York, 500 Pearl Street, New York, New York
Nine East 71st Street, New York (defendant property)
US Virgin Islands (where Epstein's will is being probated)
Paris (mentioned as a location of Epstein property)
New Mexico (mentioned as a location of Epstein property)
Florida (mentioned as a location of Epstein property and potential venue for lawsuits)
keyFacts: The Epstein estate, through its attorneys, proposed a victim compensation fund to be administered independently by Kenneth Feinberg, Jordana Feldman, and Camille Viras, aiming to resolve claims outside of litigation.

Plaintiffs' attorneys strongly criticized the estate for unilaterally creating the settlement process without their input, expressing distrust and a lack of information about estate assets and the fund's structure.
Magistrate Judge Freeman emphasized the need for genuine cooperation and plaintiff inclusion in any settlement process, urging both sides to schedule a meeting with the claims administrators.
Dozens more victim lawsuits were anticipated, with plaintiffs' attorneys reporting daily calls from new potential claimants.

The conference addressed procedural issues including pseudonymous filings, preservation of evidence (spoliation), and the coordination of discovery across multiple cases before different district judges.
